title: Stanford CS230 | Autumn 2025 | Lecture 2: Supervised, Self-Supervised, & Weakly Supervised Learning
description:
For more information about Stanford‚Äôs Artificial Intelligence professional and graduate programs, visit: https://stanford.io/ai

September 30, 2025
This lecture covers key AI concepts through case studies.

To learn more about enrolling in this course, visit: https://online.stanford.edu/courses/cs230-deep-learning

To follow along with the course schedule and syllabus, visit: https://cs230.stanford.edu/syllabus/

More lectures will be published regularly.
View the playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLoROMvodv4rNRRGdS0rBbXOUGA0wjdh1X

Andrew Ng
Founder of DeepLearning.AI
Adjunct Professor, Stanford University‚Äôs Computer Science Department

Kian Katanforoosh

comments.author: @tapu_
comments.content:
For anyone confused about when these concepts he is talking about were taught:
Andrew Ng didn't go in-depth on them on the in-person class (Lecture 1). They were instead taught on his own platform deep learning ai. The slides are in the cs230 syllabus available online

comments.author: @1Eagler
comments.content:
I remember back in the 80s when they tried to create a nn to detect tanks.
So, when the weather was good, they took the tank out and teach the nn to recognize the tank
When the weather was rough, they didnt took the tank out and teach the NN to recognize that's there isn't  a tank.
So, they built a NN to recognize thats a tank on good weather and to recognize there isn't a tank at bad weather!

comments.author: @BRichard312
comments.content: The primary problem with neural networks is that they are NOT practical to use in business largely due to their lack of interpretability and explainability. You can't just provide an output to a business leader and say "here's the answer" without describing how you got that answer along with a specific understanding of its underlying process methodology.

comments.author: @HadiJafari-x8g
comments.content: in face recognition case, how can you detect fraud? One situation that continuously goes through my mind is that what if someone stole an ID and also had a picture of the ID owner printed to show the camera? how can the model detect these situations?

replies.author: @FABIANANDRESROZO
replies.content: I am not an expert here, but i think it would be similar to the iphone features to know that is your face and not an image, using infrared points to map your face, but it is like different hardware you are using, so I think you could not tell the difference between an image and a real person in that case. Anyways I think he said that in some classes they will cover adversary techniques, so we hope them to include this case.

replies.author: @seanpaulson9098
replies.content: Id guess it could just detect micro movements in the face where an image would be still.
